replies.author: @criesinthe-night
replies.text:
Im really really sorry. That is a deep trauma. 

I also felt validated by this because i can hear awful domestic violence from my neighbors apartment and I have been feeling wracked with guilt that i dont call the police. But i dont know what to do. The cops only make things worse. And i live in a majority latin area. It doesnt feel right to call them.

Thank you for still trying to stand up for the victim. We desperately need better community interventions for things like active DV, because it can be actually threatening to try to intervene by yourself. Im also a survivor and I try to speak up when i see it in public but sometimes i shut down from the flashbacks.

replies.text: @criesinthe-night What blew my mind was learning about how it was pretty publicly acceptable to encourage it. Not even bother with the veneer but just straight up say these people, whatever else they were were US citizens, and most authorities were pretty happy to view it as a positive. There is a recording from the Reagan whitehouse where the spokesclown is just making jokes about the AIDS epidemic while a reporter, who was absolutely not ok with homosexuality, was shocked at how happy everyone in the room was about it. This homophobic guy was that blown away that the government representative was cracking jokes about the deaths of US citizens.

Charming back then and today are not the same, back then hitching a ride was seen as normal and okay, today it's practically a last resort. Just like how most people ignore hitch hikers for safety.

By today's standards bundy looks like creep even before you know of his crimes.

There are likely a few serial killers operating today and because they fit today's standard of beauty, charm, well curated not creep persona are getting away with their crimes.

author: @caitmonroe9349
text:
I've done a lot of work in prison education as a volunteer teacher, and I really appreciate your thoughtful analysis on balancing the desire for "justice" with abolition. Being inside prison facilities, even as just a visitor, was soul-crushing. The system works so hard to beat people down with an endless loop of small cruelties and larger-scale violence. Some of my students apologized for falling asleep in class because they were literally malnourished, not eating the food they were given because it was molding. It broke my heart to see a group of funny, bright people who were trying to improve their lives repeatedly treated like human refuse. 

I can't help but want to see cops suffer in the system they currently thrive in, but really, no one should be in these spaces. Thank you for the really clear articulation of why incarcerating cops changes nothing.

author: @penabler
text: The Night Stalker is one of the cases I‚Äôm obsessed with because documentaries usually use a bunch of interviews with police who did nothing but bungle the investigation. Then good ol‚Äô Dianne Feinstein put the investigation details on the news and the cops FREAKED OUT. Any article about it still frames it from the police perspective and act like she jeopardized the investigation by alerting the killer. BUT this prompted the police to share their shitty police sketch of the suspect with the papers and he was caught by regular people the very same fucking day. I think of it as a case study to how worthless police are and how stupidly deferential our media is to authority. It‚Äôs the same reason I‚Äôm obsessed with Havana Syndrome.

replies.author: @DaughterofDiogenes
replies.text: Yeah. This this this.  I‚Äôm Audhd and I say that because apparently it is common for autistic people to take in new information that conflicts with what they already know and then change thier opinion based on said credible knowledge  whereas for NTs apparently when they get new information, they double down on thier incorrect beliefs. I think this has a lot to do with why everything is so messed up. Now that I‚Äôm an adult I can tell you that all of NT society is based on lies.  People love their lies. They hate the truth and they will hate you if you say the truth. Plato was right. Never forget they straight murdered Socrates for spitting facts. And I think about that all the time. The cave analogy is so amazingly accurate. Scary accurate. And what‚Äôs even scarier is that he was writing like thousands of years ago and even with thousands of years of progress people are still stuck in the cave and seemingly want to stay there.

replies.author: @EphemeralTao
replies.text: That's a good one, because Ramirez was definitely not acting alone.  He had a cousin (Miguel Angel Valles) who was very likely also a serial killer, but was never caught or prosecuted because of who he killed.  There is also considerable evidence that certain other serial killers had partners, or that they got the wrong person entirely, but the police refused to acknowledge either of those possibilities because they "caught the killer" and didn't want to bother looking any further.

replies.author: @jennywarren
replies.text: @penabler¬† He was the only person in Los Angeles out of thousands of people worldwide to own a pair of those shoes which were the first brand to bring others to court for rights to their design. She absolutely got in the way of the investigation. It was his shoes, nothing to do with the police sketch that bungled it.

replies.author: @penabler
replies.text: @ the shoes wasn‚Äôt it. Police put his sketch in the paper, a dude saw Ramirez react to seeing his own sketch, and then dozens of regular people captured him in the street. The shoe was an excellent piece of evidence that didn‚Äôt actually have anything to do with capturing the Night Stalker. The shoe gets a lot of air time in the docs because that‚Äôs evidence the police had, among many of the salacious details of the crime scenes, and the police will be most of the talking heads. The police in this particular case have the audacity to disparage what actually lead to the capture of the guy they were trying to catch, which kind of makes the story perfect to me.

replies.author: @jennywarren
replies.text: @penabler¬† printing the sketches, unauthorized or not,was a great idea. Revealing the shoe messed up another peice of evidence which could have helped solidify the arrest even more. Things like that get cases thrown out all the time. Glad he was caught.

author: @magnolia_g
text:
I don't want cops at all, and also have no idea what to do. My first husband was killed, and nothing happened. I was abused and SA'ed as a child, and nothing happened. I was SA'ed as an adult, and nothing happened. That's just me, not any of my friends, other family or people. All was reported. Nothing happened. I don't know what to do about the DV situation across my street, other than offer help when i see the wife. Can't call the cops. 

What do we do about these monsters? This system doesn't work, I agree, what system does? I'm not being rhetorical, i ewant people to stop getting killed, hurt and abused

replies.author: @allyli1718
replies.text:
There was a good Rebecca Watson video on this. She's a science communicator, and she had noticed that in research, DV is often a prelude to shootings. Much like most people, she made the mistake of assuming that that arresting these abusers would would help prevent more attacks. (Much like you said, the average person doesn't have any idea of how we can protect ourselves without cops because that's the only system we know in America.Ôºâ

She did more research though, and it turns out policing/imprisonment only led to repeat offenses once they were out again, on top of the issue of the rampant rates of DV from police officers.  So she looked at other forms of community dv reform. There was the Duluth Model, where DV perpetrators were taught that their DV was the result of feeling entitled to power and control as a result of societal messaging, which wasn't very effective at actually creating change in the person. You can know that your actions are wrong and controlling but still struggle not to do them, as anyone with an eating disorder will tell you. And changing a mindset you've been taught by society your whole life is really hard.

A method that did help with reducing physical DV was a method called ACT, which is based on the therapy technique of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy. The idea is teaching people to recognize the links between their thoughts/emotions and behavior, and then how they can acknowledge the thoughts that lead to negative behaviors while still choosing to do the better action. You don't need to change your entire worldview, just learn how not to be controlled by it if it's hurting your life. Therapy and rehabilitation, while not feeling like "justice," pretty consistently is shown to reduce recidivism.

replies.author: @drebugsita
replies.text: @magnolia_g there are local sexual assault / domestic violence organizations that offer resources and guidance. Easy to lookup and contact

text: My perspective is that justice is restorative, punishment is corrective, and trying to make somone as miserable as their victim is just vengeance.  I'm not above wanting vengeance, but I can't lie to myself and say that any aspect of society benefits from vengeance that is neither restorative nor corrective.

author: @Revilo9991
text:
My first semester at Georgia Tech was when Scout Schultz was killed by police. I TRULY don‚Äôt give a fuck that they said in their phone call to the police that the suspicious person had a gun. An assessment of the situation would have revealed that they didn‚Äôt have one, the fact that they were walking up with a retracted multi tool saying ‚Äúshoot me‚Äù obviously suggests this person needs proper help, but the cops didn‚Äôt even opt for the less lethal (I have to remind myself to keep using that) option of the taser. Police violence is accepted with no further inquiry. Just some excuse and they move on. 

I always think back to how those police shoved a fucking 75 year old man in Buffalo and hospitalized him for at least a month. Nothing happened. Nothing at all. Someone died from a similar injury in my city not long ago. I would bet everything I have the person responsible for that accidental death will get a more significant punishment than most cops ever will for their behavior. What a terrible system.

text:
I don't know if I count as abolisionist as I think there are some individuals who are so dangerous they should be kept away from other people for the rest of their lives, or they have done so much harm allowing them to be free even if rehabilitated would cause unfair PTSD to those around them. That being said such individuals are propably much rarer than the media portrays. And I suspect a disproportionate number of such individuals would have been wearing some kind of uniform. 
Also I am aware that apparently rehabilitating justice system causes less crime. 

Also I should mention I live in Finland so I have a very different experience with cops. That being said a young Romani friend of mine has suggested she has have negative experiences with Finnish cops. Many Finns would propably excuse that with a racist stereotype about Romani people. Which to me makes her just more credible.

author: @EphemeralTao
text:
I used to be into True Crime serial killer stuff, mainly since my late wife was into it.  One thing that really struck me about pretty much all of them is just how useless the police were.  So many of these shows, as well as interviews with the real-live investigators, try make it all look it's a battle of wills, dedicated super-smart detectives tracking down a genius super-villain.  Fictional programs like _Criminal Minds_ , or dramatizations and book about real life like _Mindhunter_ .  But when you watch the actual, real documentaries and read about what really went on, the thing that really characterizes these investigations from is Incompetence and Indifference, from top to bottom.

Recently tried to re-watch a documentary on the Yorkshire Ripper, and that was the perfect example.  The police did not care at all about the murders of prostitutes; it wasn't until Suttcliffe started killing so-called "respectable" women that they finally put serious effort into tracking him down.  Along with that, the detectives very quickly decided they knew why he was killing, and how they could stop him, and refused to change their minds despite mountains of evidence they were wrong.

It's also really disturbing how many times they catch the killers and let them go, because they don't see the bleeding obvious right in front of their eyes.  Or when it's painfully obvious that the killer is actually working with a partner, and they just stop looking after catching the "one perpetrator responsible".  And, of course, there's the problem of police departments across jurisdictional boundaries refusing to work together or share information.

From what I've seen, the only serial killer I can think of who truly appeared to be somewhat clever was Zodiac; and the reason his killings stopped is probably because the police busted him for something else, somewhere else, and never noticed who he was.

replies.author: @mexcavazos
replies.text: Insightful. One question, How do you tell the difference between incompetence and "by design?" It is dismissve to excuse poor conduct by claiming it is incompetence when it is across the board and widespread. Think about it.

author: @colonelweird
text:
Cops charged with murder also get legal representation in a system designed to make conviction almost impossible. So juries can find cops not guilty even in egregious cases of police misconduct. In my neighborhood, a few years ago there was a cop who tased her victim, and after he was incapacitated, she shot him in the back & killed him. And it was all on video. The jury was instructed to accept whatever excuse her attorney invented, so the cop was found not guilty.

While refreshing my memory about this  case, I discovered that two days ago another local cop killing was deemed justified by prosecutors, so no charges will be filed.

replies.author: @kristalcampbell3650
replies.text: I used to have this fear until in my late teens.  I experienced horrible violence, the kind I was taught police exist to protect kids from, and a cop isolated me from my mother, sat in my bedroom on my bed, and outlined all of the reasons why I was not going to be protected.

replies.author: @Alieth
replies.text: @princegobi5992 how does abolition help with that?

replies.author: @Asterite100
replies.text:
@The-Doctor6969 This is also something I struggle with wrapping my head around. It's why I rarely chime in on serious topics like abolition, because I just don't have the expertise or life experience to have an opinion on either which way, despite me being anti-cop broadly speaking.

There are people out there who outright believe, for example, we need religion because then "where do our morals come from?" As if to say, without the looming threat of eternal damnation or some other retributive punishment, people will commit acts of cruelty for the sake of it. Not everyone has a sob story that turns them to crime, some people are just that broken and will never seek help through their own volition, even in a hypothetical world where mental health care is free.

Nevermind that people can commit crime anyway even if they may technically be a believer, which is part of the crux of the abolition argument that the prison complex isn't as effective a deterrent as much as it is another avenue of exploitation.

The answer is seemingly that we just need to take our defense and security into our own hands? Because functionally, that's what many Americans have to do since they cannot rely on the police anyway. It's just a bleak conversation that I hope people smarter than I will eventually find a solution to.

replies.author: @prodigal_southerner
replies.text:
Most people are fundamentally good, and most crime is a direct consequence of the environment that "criminals" are forced to live in.  It requires money to survive in this dystopian hellscape, but our wise rulers do nothing to ensure that safe, meaningful, well-paid work is available to everyone.  They still need to survive, though, so we get drug dealers and robbers out of that contradiction.  

For the people who are "lucky" enough to make enough money to barely survive, they exist in a situation of constant stress over finances.  If those people have children, they will not have the time or patience to be good parents.  Abusive or neglectful parents, which can describe parents of any socioeconomic background - see Elon Musk and his father, are more commonly impoverished people who lack the time to properly raise their children, a very fundamental part of being a human or most any mammal.  Childhood abuse or neglect is one of the most powerful predictors for whether an adult will have a cluster B personality disorder - Narcissists, borderline, and antisocial (psychopaths, colloquially.) 

The way to effectively address crime would be by making sure that everyone has enough money to survive comfortably, not criminalizing mental health problems like substance abuse, and providing support to parents to make sure they are providing for the emotional needs of their children.  That will never happen under a capitalist economy because capitalists need extreme poverty to force people to work terrible jobs for inadequate pay, which means more profits and returns for shareholders.  In the USSR, crime rates were much lower than in the United States.  Corporate media would tell you that is because they had an authoritarian government, while they had a much smaller prison population both in absolute numbers and as a percentage of the population.   The reason their crime rates were lower is because the people of that federation fought a civil war to install a government that prioritized human life and wellbeing over the financial interests of a small percentage of parasites.   Just look at how crime, addiction, and suicide exploded in Russia after the US was able to successfully overthrow the Soviet Union. Eastern Europe became the world capital for prostitution and pornography (both adult and child) in the 90s because they had a massive, new population of people who were desperate to survive after having the rug yanked out from under them.

replies.author: @prodigal_southerner
replies.text: Fun fact that I forgot to include: John Maynard Keynes, the economist responsible for the social democratic reforms in Europe and North America after the great depression, predicted that by today we would be working 2-4 hours per day because of productivity increases resulting from technological advances.  Ironically, that would put us somewhere around the average amount of work being done by Medieval peasants, who had to give a smaller fraction of what they produced to the aristocracy than what is kept by business owners.  For every dollar your employer pays you, they keep between one and four dollars of the value your labor produced.  The reason von Mises and "Austrian economists" are so fetishized by dipshits like Ayn Rand and Libertarians is because von Mises, an Austrian aristocrat who thought that the lower classes needed to be paternalistically guided by their betters, gave intellectual-soumding rationalizations for their greed.

replies.author: @hughcaldwell1034
replies.text: I know what you mean. For me the key fact is the simple mathematical reality that the cops and prisons don't make us safer. Higher incarceration rates do not lower crime rates. Harsher sentences do not lower crime rates. Our system of "lock up the bad guys so they can't hurt you" has an attractive simplicity, but it doesn't work in practice. And that's what abolitionists want - not to have no justice system or accountability, but to have one that actually makes people safer.

We were two kids walking and giggling with our dog. I almost pissed myself. We froze. He looked and started laughing at us and put his gun away. We immediately ran home and told our mom. She called the cops and got the guys badge number to complain and his excuse was that we had a pit bull that we were ‚Äúattacking him‚Äù with. We didn‚Äôt even know ow he was there. This man was such a coward that he got scared by a goofy Shar Pei on a leash and two children.

replies.author: @Methuzala777
replies.text: Not having the police is neither nihilism nor giving up. It is accepting a thing that produces a specific result over time and accepting that result as part of the design. If you put energy and effort into another plan, but give up on or change the plan that already did not correct the problem, that is not "giving up" or nihilism. However, refusing to acknowledge consistet results over time and associating them with a planned state: policing is planned, not a static concept, we police in a way or another, it is engeneered to address a problem and produce a result. Do we have a system that perpetuates and increases inequality consistently over time? If so, its a result of its design. A design that can be changed.

author: @HunterHooligan
text:
I first found you through your GoT content and have loved your reviews and watching your takes on the show. You have such an infectious joy that really gets me hype about whatever you‚Äôre reviewing. And I am somehow only just now only beginning to see your political content!

But THIS video just became a new all time favorite! I will be sharing this one for the rest of my days when trying to discuss my own views on abolition and our dreams of a world without the prison industrial complex. Thank you so much for making this video and for all the work you do. üíôüôè

Insightful. One question to anyone reading this, how do you tell the difference between incompetence and "by design?" 
It is dismissve to excuse poor conduct by claiming it is incompetence when it is so widespread and across the board. 
Think about it.

author: @sadie1606
text:
‚ÄúWhat would we do without institutionalized punishment?‚Äù
The same thing we do now, because we barely have institutionalized punishment. 
We have punishment for the disadvantaged and mentally ill, the most vulnerable people.. we dont have punishment for crime. 

Cis YT men get away with horrific crimes daily, its not a criminal justice system, its the department of continued oppression.
